text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that the fire report being 'sufficient and suitable' is the responsibility of the owner if the report has been incorrectly completed by the third-party inspector. The candidate answer addresses this under the 'Suitable & Sufficient FRA' section: 'FRA omission of PAT/electrical shorts (common fire cause, per LFB stats) could be criticized as insufficient (FSO requires \"all significant risks\").' Furthermore, under the 'Disadvantages/Risks' for the FRA, it notes: 'Independent third-party FRA is strong evidence of diligence (courts value experts, e.g., R v Tangerine Confectionery [2011]). No PAT mention = not your gap if focused on \"fire\" (not electrical).' While it doesn't explicitly state the owner is *responsible* for the third party's error, it clearly frames the *insufficiency* of the report (even if outsourced) as a major risk/disadvantage to the owner, implying the owner bears the ultimate burden of ensuring suitability under FSO Art.9, which is the core concept tested by the criterion.", "criterion_id": "96af97b1-4044-42bb-9b71-15102a04a27e"}
